Based on his reading of particular Sanskrit texts, he created an image of the Buddha that reflected some of the preferences of a segment of nineteenth century European society (rationalism, individual morality, opposition to the supernatural and superstition) and distinguished the historical Buddha from the practices in India that they viewed as degenerate (Lopez 2013: 210-211). This is not to say that the Europeans fabricated these traits of Siddharta or the connections between different regions, but the specific form of the connections and the narrative of Siddharta that the Europeans emphasized were not the only stories and ways of organizing the world. 
These selections and constructions from Europeans have influence outside of European and English-language representations of Buddhism, as the Europeans authorized particular leaders as authoritative and emphasized certain practices over others. For example, the European emphasis on textual sources as the true religion confirmed the assertions of some in Ceylon that their form of Buddhism, based on the Pali Canon (which they determined are the oldest texts available about Siddharta), had more authority, and these assertions also reinforced the position of the monks in Ceylon as the prime example of Buddhism there, contrasting to the corrupted practices of the common people, many of whom included the worship of deities or even praying to the Buddha as a god.
Area: India, Sri Lanka/Ceylon, China, Japan, Tibet

Title: British Indian Census
Content:
As colonizers, British officials wanted as much data as possible about the people of British India, considering that as beneficial to maintain their growing control over the region. In the second half of the nineteenth century, they initiated the first census of India, which included questions about religious identification. However, the question arose what religious labels to use, a question that remains, to an extent, a matter of debate, even after Indian independence. 
The British recognized clear distinctions between Hinduism and Islam, though some people participated in rituals associated with both, much to the consternation of the colonizers. More complicated, though, was a distinction, if one existed, between indigenous practices and Hinduism. At what point should a person be identified as Hindu or indigenous? For some in British India, identifying according to these religious labels was not a part of their self-understanding, so the colonizers had to train census takers how to differentiate between different identities, if the person themselves did not have a ready answer. 
A politically charged question arose about the relation of Sikhs to Hinduism. Was Sikhism a guru movement within Hinduism or a separate religion? In the census of the Punjab in 1855, Hinduism was the broader category, with no separate label for Sikhs, which lead to complaints by some who identified as Sikhs. Others rejected a separate identification for Sikhism. The issue influenced dynamics in Punjab, as separating out Sikhs altered the percentages of Hindus vs. Muslims. The separate identification from 1872 Ð on led to Sikh demands for inclusion of separate seats for Sikhs on some local governing bodies.
Branch: Bhakti, Vedanta, Vedic, Khalsa, Nanak Panthi

Title: Singh Sabha Movement Begins
Content:
The Punjabi region in the last half of the nineteenth century had a significant presence of British colonialism, Christian missionaries, and reformers (often from other regions of British India) who promoted different visions of religion, particularly Hinduism. After several Sikh students at a mission school in Amritsar announced their conversion to Christianity in 1873, some community leaders, identifying with Sikhism ,established the Singh Sabha of Amritsar to discuss Sikhism and promote its stability. The organizers feared that young people were susceptible to conversion, thus threatening Sikh traditions. They took action to counter their exposure to Christianity in mission schools and pressures for different religious conceptions from reform movements like the Brahmo Samaj and (later) the Arya Samaj. The Arya Samaj, in particular claimed that Sikhs are really Hindu and attempted to bring the followers of Nanak back into a reformed Hinduism. The Amritsar Singh Sabha began to codify and publish elements of Sikh narrative and practices, such as the lives of the gurus and celebration of their births. In 1879 another Singh Sabha developed in Lahore. 
The two initial Singh Sabhas promoted different emphases about Sikhism. The Amritsar Singh Sabha and the traditions that it promoted defined Sikhism broadly, including much contemporary practice that connected with devotional practices such as the worship of images of deities. In contrast, the Lahore Singh Sabha placed their emphasis on a distinct Khalsa Sikh identity and practice as the true form of Sikhism, rejecting any devotion to images of deities or other gurus. The assertions of the Lahore Singh Sabha gained prominence over the next several decades.

Title: Arya Samaj Founded
Content:
As British India experienced significant change in the nineteenth century, some thinkers in the region developed their own ideas about what Hinduism should be. Dayananda Saraswati was one of those thinkers, and he developed an interpretation of the Vedas that he used to argue for the reform of Hinduism. He founded the Arya Samaj in 1875 to propagate these ideas, and the movement spread across northern regions of British India. 
Saraswati identified the Vedas as the primary authority in Hinduism, and through that rejected many traditional narratives and practices. Stories about different deities, such as the epics (Ramayana and Mahabharata) and the Puranas were displaced by a focus on the meaning of the Vedas. Instead of devotion to statues of deities in temples, he promoted a ritual where participants throw herbs into a fire while reciting Sanskrit as the primary ritualized practice. He also promoted the education of women and a rejection of caste based on birth, all drawing on his reading of the Vedas. The Arya Samaj also began an effort to bring people into the true practice of Hinduism, including reconverting some who had begun identifying with other religions (such as Sikhism, Christianity, and Islam). 
While the language of the Arya Samaj emphasized ancient ideas and texts of South Asia and the movement tried to replace British schools in British India with their Vedic education, the movement also adopted certain assumptions that can be seen as modern European ideas. For example, the ultimate authority of the oldest text was more of a long-standing European emphasis than a common conception in India. Their campaigns to educate women, oppose widow burning, reject worship of images, and remove discrimination based on caste birth addressed critiques of Indian society that colonizers commonly emphasized in the colonizersÕ efforts to present India as inferior.

Title: World Parliament of Religion
Content:
The World Columbian Exposition in Chicago in 1893 had a famous midway with exhibits highlighting exotic elements from around the world. An ancillary event, the World Parliament of Religions, brought together figures representing a variety of religions, both the familiar and exotic. The organizers wanted to promote particular images of human unity, while also demonstrating the supremacy of Christianity on a unified, global stage. The organizers were listed by Christian denomination, with the exception of one who was  identified as Jewish. 
The official list of participants labeled them in ways that highlight the complicated boundaries defining religions at the time. Most participants were linked to their leadership position in an institution, such as the African Methodist Episcopal Church, the Church of England, the Jain Association of India, and the Zikko Sect of Shintoism, to name only a few. Several Buddhist institutions also provided contexts for participants, such as the Southern Buddhist Church of Ceylon and the Buddhist Church of Japan. In relation to institutions and communities in India, a few participants were identified with the Brahmo-Samaj and one with Allahabad College (also identified as a Theosophist), while some were listed without an institution (Mohammedan and Hindu monk). Across the entire list, a few were labeled as converts to Christianity, including Òa native African prince from LiberiaÓ and one Òfrom Parseeism, Bombay, IndiaÓ. The list also labeled some differently than the others, including the previous person labeled as Thesopohist, an Idealist from Germany, and a member of the Chinese Legation Òto present the doctrine of ConfuciusÓ. 
The various identifications illustrate the growing standardization of religious boundaries. Hinduism and Buddhism can be seen as relatively distinct in this list of participants, as is Parseeism, Shintoism, and Mohammedanism, though these particular labels have shifted to Zoroastrianism, Shinto, and Islam, respectively, in the years since. Whether Theosophy, Idealism, and Confucianism were seen as religions equivalent to others is less clear from the list but implicit as they were attendees at the World Parliament of Religions. Some communities commonly included in the twenty-first century, though, were absent from the event, including indigenous traditions of various parts of the world, Sikhism, and Taoism.
Area: India, Sri Lanka/Ceylon, China, Japan, Tibet

Title: Vedanta Society of New York Founded
Content:
In the aftermath of the 1893 World Parliament of Religions, perhaps the most famous participant was Swami Vivekananda, the ÒHindu monk from India.Ó In India, he was associated with the founding of the Ramakrishna Mission, named for one of his influential teachers of Vedanta. Attendees at the Parliament and the press appreciated his assertions about uniting humanity, drawing on this Vedantic thought. He toured in the United States, giving lectures for several years immediately after the Parliament and later returned to give additional lectures in 1899 in both the US and Europe. 
His popularity in some circles in the US and Europe drew on the intersection of European and produced a new set of institutions in the US. Scholars debate whether the leaders of the Brahmo Samaj or Ramakrishna had the greater influence on Vivekananda. The Brahmo SamajÕs modern interpretation of a monotheistic and rational theology encouraged an interpretation of Hinduism that would be more amenable among his wealthy patrons in the United States and Europe, but others assert that his encounter with his teacher Ramakrishna (and his view of the unity of all religions) shaped his representation of Vedanta to audiences outside of India. In 1894, during his first trip, he established the Vedanta Society of New York, and in his second trip he worked to establish and strengthen additional centers.

Title: Hindutva Ideology Developed
Content:
An ideology that argues that Hindu identity is central to Indian culture, known as Hindutva, developed in the writings of Vinayak Damodar Savarkar, who published a pamphlet ÒHindutvaÓ in 1923. Savarkar presented his own definition of being Hindu, tying that identity to seeing India as both the fatherland and holy land. Such a definition expands Hindu to encompass Buddhism, Jainism, and Sikhism, as they all began in the region, while distinguishing those identities clearly from Christian and Muslim identities, whose holy land is outside of India, as Savarkar delineates it. This ideology thus fostered the concept that Hindus (broadly defined) are the natural citizens of India, and Muslims and Christians are not, making them perhaps second-class citizens or, worse, foreign threats. 
The development of this ideology during the Indian Independence movement reflects the fears of some about an independent India. After the Indian National Congress (led by Gandhi) cooperated with the Muslim League in the Khilafat movement, some feared the Muslim communityÕs influence in an independent India, considering it a threat against Hindu communities. Even after the Partition of India into Muslim majority Pakistan and Hindu majority India (roughly), some Hindus in India have promoted SavarkarÕs Hindutva, which is now commonly associated with Hindu nationalist groups and the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP). The BJP has frequently held power in India since 1996. Hindutva proponents, as one example, have complained about benefits given to Muslims, seeing those coming at the expense of the ÒrealÓ citizens of India, the Hindus. The equation of India with Hindu also became justification for government promoting Hindu practices such as yoga. Anyone who resists practices associated with Hinduism are seen then as anti-India, confirming the concerns of Hindutva through a circular logic.

Title: Sikh Gurdwara Act
Content:
Following a significant protest movement led by Sikhs, particularly those associated with the Singh Sabha of Lahore and its progeny, the Chief Khalsa Diwan, the British Indian government passed the Sikh Gurdwara Act in 1925. The concern of the protest movement was the leadership and policies of gurdwaras, sometimes referred to as Sikh temples. The British had recognized the leadership of the majority of gurdwaras held by Udasis, an ascetic group who spread the teachings of Nanak, his son, and the other gurus associated with Sikhs. The vision of Sikh practice that Udasis employed in gurdwaras incorporated the images of deities identified as Hindu and various gurus in addition to Nanak and his ten successors (including the Guru Granth Sahib, the text recognized as the central text of Sikhs and their living guru). Protestors considered these inclusions in gurdwaras as corruptions of the teaching of Sikhism, which they saw as rejecting both image worship and reverence for anything above the Guru Granth Sahib. 
The Sikh Gurdwara Act of 1925 created a new body, the Shiromani Gurdwara Prabhandchak Committee (SGPC) to have control over gurdwaras in Punjab and Delhi. This committee was to be elected by Sikhs, giving them autonomy over their places of devotion. The rejection of the position of the Udasis effectively legislated the separation of Sikhism from Hinduism, signaling the victory of the Lahore Singh Sabha over the position of the Amritsar Singh Sabha as to what the tradition of Sikhism included. 
The election of the SGPC did not resolve all questions of what counts as Sikhism, as debates continued over the next century as to who should have the right to vote for the SGPC. Some considered only Khalsa Sikhs should be recognized, while others expanded it to any Sikh who keeps their hair uncut, commonly known as Keshdhari or Sehajdhari Sikhs.

Title: Mosque/Temple Conflict in Ayodhya
Content:
The Babri Masjid (mosque) in Ayodhya in north India became the renewed site of conflicts related to religion. The mosque was built in 1528, but since at least the mid-nineteenth century some have claimed that the mosque was built after a Muslim invader destroyed a temple marking the birthplace of Rama, the deity who is an avatar of Vishnu described in the Ramayana. Thus, some who identified as Hindu demanded the removal of the mosque and the reconstruction of the temple. 
In December 1949, government leaders locked the mosque, preventing prayers there, after statues of Rama appeared inside the mosque. Some devotees considered it a miracle, proving that the site was RamaÕs birthplace, but others contended that priests placed the images in the mosque to bolster the Hindu claims to the site. Lawsuits before courts in India presented various points, including an archaeological exploration that determined a structure lay underneath the mosque, which some claimed was a Hindu temple and others a Buddhist temple. Throughout these cases, other temples in Ayodhya continued to claim to be the birthplace of Rama. 
The various court cases continued to be delayed for decades. In 1992, a group of devotees to Rama tore down the mosque by hand, leading to riots across India pitting Muslims against Hindus. The violence came after a Hindu nationalist political campaign focused on the claims of Hindus to the site. In 2002, many volunteers visited Ayodhya to prepare for temple construction on the remains of the mosque. A fire on a train carrying a group of volunteers home to Gujarat killed a number of these devotees. Violence in response led to the loss of many lives, primarily identified as Muslim, in Gujarat. 
In 2019, the Supreme Court of India made a final ruling, giving control of the site to a group of Hindu to build a temple while also giving control of land in another part of Ayodhya and a trust to the Muslim community to build a new mosque. In 2024, the partly complete temple to Rama marking his birthplace (according to some) was consecrated.

Title: Krishna Consciousness Comes to the US
Content:
In 1965, a man arrived in the United States from India with the mission to spread Krishna Consciousness. Prabhupada came to the US from Kolkatta, India, following the instructions of his guru to spread devotion to Krishna beyond India. He began chanting the Mahamantra (Hare Krishna, Hare Krishna, Krishna, Krishna, Hare Hare É) in New York City and teaching inquisitive youth to chant the mantra and pursue their true nature by being devoted to Krishna. 
Soon after arriving, he and his students established the International Society of Krishna Consciousness (ISKCON), which over time established temples across the United States, primarily attracting US youth who were critical of American society and religion. His followers regularly chanted the Mahamantra on street corners and college campuses, as well as offering books about Krishna, including the Bhagavad Gita and PrabhupadaÕs commentary on it, for a donation to ISKCON. Some of these followers left their homes to live in the temples and give continual devotion to Krishna and Prabhupada. 
Some in the US began to label ISKCON (commonly referred to as Hare Krishnas) as a cult, or at least a New Religious Movement. The separation of some of his followers from family and their critique of normal adulthood contributed to that labeling, even though PrabhupadaÕs lineage goes back centuries to Caitanya (sixteenth century CE). Some legislation against their public practices developed, most notably restrictions on their request for donations / sale of flowers or books around airports. 
After PrabhupadaÕs death, the community continued, though some conflicts over leadership and scandals about some of the leaders hurt the movementÕs reputation. With increasing immigration from India, ISKCON temples began to attract a mix of immigrants from South Asia, many who migrated for economic and professional opportunities, and non-immigrant converts to ISKCON who often rejected those economic and professional opportunities, creating intriguing community dynamics. 
Between the Indian immigrants who participated in ISKCON temples and followers of Prabhupada who were not of Indian heritage, the movement gained enough status to begin sending committed followers to India to spread Krishna Consciousness there. These emissaries to India have received a mixed reception, especially when they do not fit particular assumptions of the common appearance of Hindus in modern India.
